transcript:
Therapist: You've done a great job today, Marcus, in recognizing the connections between your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. As we wrap up our session, I want to leave you with a homework assignment that will help you continue practicing the skills we've discussed.

Patient: Okay, I'm ready for the homework. What do you have in mind?

Therapist: For this week, I'd like you to continue using the thought records and positive data log. Additionally, I want you to practice cognitive restructuring with at least one negative thought that comes up during the week. Write down the evidence for and against the thought, consider alternative perspectives, and generate a more balanced and helpful thought. We'll review your homework together in our next session.

Patient: That sounds doable. I'll make sure to set aside time each day to work on the thought records and practice cognitive restructuring.

Therapist: Great! Remember, the more you practice these skills, the easier it will become to catch and reframe negative thoughts in the moment. Before we end our session, I want to check in on your current mood and see if you have any final thoughts or questions.

Patient: I'm feeling a bit tired, but also hopeful. It's good to know that I'm making progress and learning skills to manage my depression. I don't have any specific questions right now, but I'll let you know if something comes up during the week.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel tired after a therapy session. You've done a lot of hard work today. Remember to take care of yourself and engage in activities that help you recharge. If any questions or concerns arise during the week, don't hesitate to bring them up in our next session.

Patient: Thank you, I appreciate your support and guidance. I'm looking forward to our next session and continuing this journey.

Therapist: You're welcome, Marcus. I'm here to support you every step of the way. Let's plan to meet at our regular time next week. In the meantime, take care of yourself, and remember to practice the skills we've discussed.

Patient: Sounds good. I'll see you next week. Thank you again for everything.

Therapist: You're welcome. Have a good week, and remember, progress isn't always linear. Be patient and compassionate with yourself as you continue to work on managing your depression.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed and practiced cognitive restructuring technique
  - Challenged negative thoughts related to setting boundaries and relationships
  - Explored the connection between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors (CBT triangle)
  - Checked in on patient's mood and progress with thought records and positive data log

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records (ongoing from previous sessions)
  - Self-compassion practice (ongoing from previous sessions)
  - Boundary-setting language and practice (ongoing from previous session)
  - Positive data log (ongoing from previous session)
  - Cognitive restructuring (new)

- Homework assigned:
  - Continue using thought records to challenge negative thoughts
  - Continue with the positive data log, focusing on small moments of accomplishment or joy each day
  - Practice cognitive restructuring with at least one negative thought that comes up during the week

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details:
  - Patient reported some ups and downs in mood since the last session, with good days and bad days
  - Identified challenges with setting boundaries at work and in relationships
  - Depression symptoms continue to include negative self-talk, feelings of overwhelm, and difficulty getting out of bed on some days
  - Patient showed insight and motivation to practice new skills and challenge negative thoughts

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I need to be available and accommodating at all times, or people will think I'm lazy or selfish"
  - Intermediate belief: "If I set boundaries, I'll miss out on opportunities and damage my relationships"

- Important information to carry forward to future sessions:
  - Continue monitoring patient's progress with boundary-setting, thought records, and cognitive restructuring
  - Review positive data log and celebrate wins in the next session
  - Explore any new challenges or insights that come up in the week ahead

- Plan for the next session:
  - Review patient's experience with homework assignments, including cognitive restructuring practice, thought records, and positive data log
  - Discuss any challenges or questions that came up while practicing new skills
  - Continue exploring beliefs about setting boundaries, relationships, and self-worth, and introduce additional techniques for challenging these beliefs as appropriate
  - Check in on patient's overall mood and any changes in depression symptoms
